III.    Facility Identification

The AFM facility is located at 1301 Oak Street in Elwood, Kansas.  Affiliated Foods Midwest cooperative is a wholesale food distribution and warehousing cooperative that specializes in fresh produce, meats, deli products, baked goods, dairy items, and frozen foods, as well as general merchandise and equipment.   



The NAICS code for the facility is 424410.  A large portion of the warehouse/distribution center is refrigerated to preserve products for distribution.   



The facility uses ammonia for refrigeration, and is regulated under 40 CFR Part 68, the EPA RMP Rule. There is one (1) refrigeration system onsite that is used for refrigerating coolers and freezers in the warehouse/distribution center. 



The amount of ammonia being charged to the refrigeration system is approximately 21,000 pounds.  The refrigeration system is used to cool  freezers, coolers, docks, produce, and banana rooms.  This refrigeration system uses ammonia refrigerant in a two (2) stage evaporation/condensation cycle.  The ammonia related equipment could be divided into three sections. The "low pressure" equipment contains (2) Ice Cream Freezer Evaporators, (2) Holding Freezer Evaporators, (1) Low Temperature Pump Package (LTPR), (1) Oil Pot and (1) Booster Compressor.  The "intermediate pressure" equipment contains (2) 28 degree Meat Cooler Evaporators, (2) 55 degree Dry Produce Evaporators, (1) 35 degree Wet Produce Evaporator, (2) 35 degree Dry Produce Evaporator, (1) 45 degree Dry Produce Evaporators, (1) 35 degree Staging Evaporator, (8) Banana Room Evaporators, (1) High Temperature Pump Package (HTPR), (1) Oil Pot, (1) Swing Compressor, and (2) High Stage Compressors.  The "high-pressure" equipment includes the (1) Evaporative Condenser and (1) Thermosyphon/High Pressure Rec

eiver (TSHPR) and associated piping/valves.





IV.    Hazard Assessment - Worse Case Scenarios (WCS)

Appendix B consists of the RMP*Submit Printout and contains additional information on the worst-case scenario.  Appendix C consists of the offsite consequence analysis data and maps for the worse case release scenario. 



V.    Hazard Assessment - Alternative Release Scenarios (ARS)

Appendix B consists of the RMP*Submit Printout and contains additional information on the alternative release scenario.  Appendix D consists of the offsite consequence analysis data and maps for the alternative release scenario. 



VI.    General Accidental Release Prevention Program

A prevention program has been developed to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and the EPA Risk Management Program.   



This prevention program covers those processes that handle ammonia above the threshold quantity for both PSM and RMP rules. The first audit of the PSM program will occur by February 24, 2012, in compliance with the requirement to conduct PSM audits every three years.  The elements of the PSM / Program 3 prevention program and a brief description are listed below.

?    Employee Participation - Affiliated Foods Midwest has developed a site-specific employee participation plan that ensures employees and their representatives are consulted when conducting and developing process hazard analyses and other information required to be developed under the PSM/RMP regulation.  In addition, the employee participation program will ensure employees and their representatives have access to process hazard analyses and all other information required to be developed under PSM/RMP.  

?    Process Safety Information - Affiliated Foods Midwest maintains a site-specific PSI program that ensures information pertaining to the hazards, technology, and equipment of the process are properly developed and maintained. Process

safety information for the ammonia process has been compiled and was last reviewed on February 24, 2012.

?    Process Hazard Analysis - Affiliated Foods Midwest has developed a site-specific PHA program that ensured a PHA was conducted initially, at a minimum of every five (5) years, and whenever a change is significant enough to require a change in PSI.  In addition, this program ensures PHAs are conducted in accordance with OSHA and EPA regulations and ensures findings and recommendations of PHAs are properly documented. Affiliated Foods Midwest conducted a thorough, initial, PHA study for the refrigeration system during February 2012.

?    Operating Procedures - Affiliated Foods Midwest has developed a site-specific procedure that ensures operating procedures provide clear instruction for different phases of process operations and ensures they are properly maintained.  Affiliated Foods Midwest developed initial operating procedures for the refrigeration system during February 2012.  Annually, the operating procedures will be reviewed and certified as accurate.

?    Training - Affiliated Foods Midwest has developed a site-specific training procedure that ensures employees operating the ammonia process have the knowledge to safely operate the process, are aware of the potential hazards of the process, and understand the causes of process problems.

 

?    Management of Change - Affiliated Foods Midwest has developed a site-specific management of change procedure that ensures changes (except for replacement in kind) to the ammonia process, such as additions of new equipment or changes in operating, maintenance, or other procedures are documented. 

?    Pre-Startup Review - Affiliated Foods Midwest has developed a site-specific pre-startup safety review procedure that ensures a safety review is performed when modifications to the ammonia process are significant enough to require a change in PSI.

?    Mechanical Integrity - Affiliated Foods Midwest has developed a site-specific

mechanical integrity procedure that ensures written preventative maintenance procedures are developed and maintained, preventative maintenance tests and inspections are properly documented, and employees maintaining the process receive adequate training.  Affiliated Foods Midwest formalized maintenance procedures for the refrigeration system during February 2012.

?    Contractor Qualifications - Affiliated Foods Midwest has developed a site-specific contractor qualification procedure that ensures all contract employers' safety performance and programs are evaluated, a contract employee injury and illness log is maintained, information of potential hazards are communicated between Affiliated Foods Midwest and the contract employer, and required training and information is communicated, such as the provisions of the emergency response plan and control over entrance into process areas.

?    Incident Investigation - Affiliated Foods Midwest has developed a site-specific incident investigation procedure that ensures each incident that either results in a release or could have resulted in a release of anhydrous ammonia is investigated, within 48 hours, by a team of at least one person knowledgeable in the process.  This procedure will also make provisions to ensure a report is prepared at the conclusion of the investigation and findings are promptly addressed. 

?    Compliance Audit - Affiliated Foods Midwest has developed a site-specific compliance audit program that ensures compliance audits are conducted at a minimum of every three years to verify that Affiliated Foods Midwest PSM/RMP practices and procedures are adequate and are being followed.  An initial compliance audit will be conducted by February 24, 2015.  

?    Hot Work Permits - Affiliated Foods Midwest has dveloped a best management practice for hot work.  Affiliated Foods Midwest developed their hot work permit procedures for the refrigeration system during February 2012.

 



VII.    Five-Year Accident History

The

Affiliated Foods Midwest facility has not yet charged the ammonia refrigeration system and therefore has not experienced an accidental anhydrous ammonia release, which resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.



VIII.    Emergency Response Program

Affiliated Foods Midwest has developed an Emergency Response Plan (ERP) to ensure that in the event of an emergency the facility personnel are aware of the appropriate actions to take and authorities to contact in order to mitigate the effects of a release. 



Upon facility start-up, Affiliated Foods Midwest will communicate and train facility employees on proper evacuation procedures and will interact (i.e. onsite inspections) with the Elwood Fire Department. 



Upon facility start-up, Affiliated Foods Midwest will coordinate their ERP with the Elwood Fire Department.  This coordination effort includes providing the agency with a copy of our ERP, and providing a site diagram and hazardous material information, meeting with Elwood Fire Department personnel to discuss the facilities operations/processes, and encouraging periodic on-site inspections and coordination with Elwood Fire Department personnel.



Affiliated Foods Midwest's maintenance department will have designated personnel as members of the emergency response team and will be responsible for investigating and assisting the Elwood Fire Department (if necessary) with response to accidental releases of ammonia. 



The facility has two (2) windsocks onsite for use in determining wind direction in the event of an ammonia release and evacuation of the building.  The windsocks are located on the Southeast and Southwest corners of the warehouse. 





IX.    Emergency Communications

The telephone numbers of agencies and plant personnel that may be contacted in case of an emergency are available onsite.

 



X.    Planned Changes to Imp

rove Safety

Chemical safety is an important part of Affiliated Foods Midwest operations. Affiliated Foods Midwest is currently implementing their Process Safety Management Program. Continuous improvement in safety is an important goal for Affiliated Foods Midwest.  



XI.    Management Program

Affiliated Foods Midwest has updated a management system to oversee the implementation of the risk management program elements.  This system has assigned qualified person(s) (or position) to assist in the development, implementation, and integration of the risk management program elements.  If any portion of the program is delegated to others, the names or positions of those individuals will be documented and the lines of authority defined through an organization chart or similar document.  Currently, Sean Guffy, Facilities Manager, is the PSM / RMP Coordinator and Bill McGuire, Warehouse Director, is responsible for implementation of the overall Risk Management Program.
